MissionCommands.Message: Welcome to the Computer lesson, where we will learn about the on-board Lunar Guidance Computer! Press F4 to switch into the Lunar Module.
This chapter will cover the basics, and if you are familiar with the Apollo Guidance Computer, most of this will be familiar.
The Lunar Guidance Computer is a control computer located in the Lunar Module, and is operated through a Display and Keyboard panels (DSKY).
It can be found on Panel 4 (don't mistake this for the Abort Guidance System on Panel 6).
The Computer is generally referenced to as the Lunar Guidance Computer (LGC). The LGC processes data and issues discrete control signals for the PGNS and other systems.
The LGC can run one major mode (mission program) at a time. It is controlled by using something called VERBs and NOUNs.
A VERB is an action that is to be performed, like changing the mission program, monitor data, change data etc.
A NOUN is the location or register the VERB (action) is being performed.
For example, if the flight crew wish to run major mode 63, they enter VERB 37 that means ACTION: CHANGE PROGRAM (MAJOR MODE), and NOUN 63 that means TO PROGRAM 63.
This will basically run program 63, the program used to initialize lunar descent.
Before interacting with the LGC DSKY, increase the brightness of the digits using the ANUN/NUM knob.
Let's try to change the major program to Program 00, the idling program.
First of all, press VERB on the DSKY.
Then press 3 as the first verb digit.
Then press 7 as the 2nd verb digit.
Then press ENTR. Usually you can first insert a VERB, then press NOUN and enter two more digits before pressing ENTER, but Verb 37 is special.
The LGC now knows the next two inputs will be a NOUN. Press 0.
Then press 0 again, so the NOUN field contains 00.
Then press ENTR to execute the command.
Now the computer will start running P00 - the idle program.
Let's also learn how to read data, and change data.
The LGC controls a very important feature, the DAP. The DAP stands for the Digital Autopilot and is used to automatically maneuver the spacecraft.
We will go through the details of the DAP in the flight modes lesson, so you don't need to understand what all this means yet. Focus on the LGC.
To modify the DAP, an extended verb is used. These verbs can request and perform actions. One Verb is dedicated to run the DAP setup.
Again, press VERB.
Then insert 4 as the first digit.
Then insert 8 as the 2nd digit.
Then press ENTR.
This will display data in the first register field named R1, and in the 2nd register field named R2. The last register field is named R3.
The data we are interested in is located in R1. Each of these digits represents a setting. You can read the data like this: ABCDE.

If the A digit contains 2, it means that you tell the DAP that you are in a configuration where both the ASCENT stage and the DESCENT stage are part of the LM, while a 3 would be this and that you are docked with the CSM.
You will learn more about this later. For now, we wish to change the DAP setup-string.
A set of verbs are available for changing one or many of the registers. We wish to change register 1 (R1).
Press VERB.
Press 2.
Press 1.
Press ENTR.
R1 will now clear, indicating it is ready to accept input digits. Most NOUNs are DECIMAL numbers. DECIMAL numbers require you to start the input with the sign (+ or -).
However, some NOUNs are OCTAL numbers. These do not support a sign and you have to enter numbers directly without the use of a sign.
NOUN 46 is an OCTAL so we will input the DAP setup string without using a sign. You can identify OCTALs by not seeing the SIGN in front of the numbers.
Enter 32011 as the number you wish to enter, then press ENTR again.
Now, press PRO to proceed to the next setup screen. PRO is used to proceed in a functional flow, while ENTR is used for data entry.
A new set of a VERB and NOUN configuration is displayed, and looking up in the Reentry Lunar Module Flight manual, this is the weights of the LM and the CSM, and are DECIMAL numbers.
DECIMAL numbers can be identified in the LGC registers by having a SIGN in front of the numbers, like in this case.
We will not perform any changes here, so press PRO to continue.
The setup is now done, and the DAP is configured to 32011.
As a challenge, are you able to find that DAP configuration again? Verb 04 can be used to display two octal numbers, one in R1 and another in R2, and the DAP exists in Noun 46.
Each NOUN decides what data is related to it. For example, in this case NOUN 46 is TWO OCTAL, meaning it has two octal numbers, and must be displayed using something that can show this, Verb 04.
We barely touched the surface here, but please go through the Reentry Lunar Module Flight Manual to learn what Verbs, Nouns and Programs exists, and how to work with them.
As we progress through the next lessons, we will learn more and more about the LGC, so don't feel overwhelmed.
Anyways, that's it for now, have a good day!

Title: Lesson 5 - Lunar Guidance Computer
Description: In the previous lessons, you learned about the RCS system. In this lesson, we will learn how to operate the computer, and some of its basic functionality.
BriefingText:
BRIEFING

Instructor: Patrick
Level: Advanced

In this lesson, we will start using the Lunar Guidance Computer (LGC). The LGC is a highly sophisticated computer used for guidance, navigation and control. It communicates with many of the subsystems in the Lunar Module, and will be one of your primary tools during a lunar flight.
